instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Good Evening, 

Customer brought in a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with a green light and nothing going on other than that.
After some digging around i found out that it had no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Restored that and now the machine wont do anything else.
Did some measuring around and i found that <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>, is shorted.
Is there something i m missing or does that mean that the cpu is fried?
Machine has been ultrasoniced and of course messed around by previous stores.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: How do you know it's shorted? The CPU VCore line is a LOW voltage line it should have a low resistance/diode mode reading normally....why did it have no PPBUS was there a short corrosion etc? If shorted, what component?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"i found out that it had no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Restored that"
What exactlly did you find there?

Do you get Magsafe light, any S5, or SUS voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
When i say it's shorted i mean that resistance to ground is 0?hm. Diode mode reading is 0.00v.
I restored <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> by replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR>-7311-7320-7321. As I said before this board has been messed with already.
Using an original 60w magsafe 2 adapter i get a green light that turns amber as it should.
Using a dc power supply at 16.5V 4A , it shows a reading of 0.150A as soon as you plug the charger but it drops to 0.020 in a matter of seconds.
I suppose that something is preventing it from starting.
There is nothing getting hot.
There is <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> but no <SIGNAL>PP3V_S5</SIGNAL>.
I have checked everything corresponding to that line and everything seems in place. 
My assumption is that a power line beyond that, meaning an s4 or s3 line is having an issue and that's why it is not powering up.
I have also replaced <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, and the smc from an excact same donor board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"I restored <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> by replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR>-7311-7320-7321"
Important thing, which you didn't consider to mention in first post.
Pretty sure you have dead CPU now; less than 1% chance to survive VCORE overvoltage.
Don't waste more time with this board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR> was shorted, this board is done. CPU got 12.6 volts RIP.
